review_title: Treatment by supervisors or scheduling clerks
job_title: Certified Health Care Aide in Winnipeg, MB
pros: You work one on one with seniors, who are great and appreciate the work you do and your level of training.
cons: I find the supervisors to not know the "real world" working situation, as they are across the city in a head office and do not see the communication, look out for safety, adaptability (as your schedule is always changing clients) and reporting/observing skills you have to use daily to do a good job. They seemed more about getting 'a number of clients" off their desk and fitting it into your schedule , even if it meant that used up a much needed put your feet up for 15 mins. coffee break. But yet they repeated, take your time, safety, do a thorough job, etc.

pros: Training and vacation time are good
cons: Working in a call center

job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Winnipeg, MB
pros:
Great work culture, most co staff have sense of camaraderie. The hospital is at the forefront of cardiac research and this reflects in its extensive Cardiac Health Specialty and services- thus provides great education to its staff as well. This culture of continuous learning spreads wide to other departments as well. 
Bonus as an employee is its central location quick step out to nice a riverwalk or all the way to the Forks, a walk to the French Catholic Cathedral, great sushi shop across the bridge and interspersed quaint shops along Provencher: a cheese, and chocolate shop.
cons: Parking is tough but as an employee one can look up private parkings by owners. Work and life balance -0 commute- bought a house there due to perfect location for leisure -rowing, parks, community center, and hospital work.

pros: Compassionate environment, room to grow and network
cons: Rigid schedule, not a very diverse work environment

pros: The pay is decent and you almost never have to work late.
cons: lots of stress, terrible management

pros: I have been very happy with my employment here in the corporate head office.  The compensation I am receiving is above average compared to other urban centres.  The employers is very flexible & reasonable with vacations and other request for time off.  It is very accepting of my opinions pertaining to improving the process with my job. I have been in the same position for almost 4 years now.  My job desciption has evolved over time so it feels like I got a promotion of sort.
cons: Because it is funded by the government don't expect any bonuses or lavish parties when the times are good. Conversely during this economic downturn there wasn't a dramatic cut to the payroll or in my department.

review_title: Adult Emergency  trauma centre - watch for burnout and gossip
pros:
Well experienced senior staff
Great learning/ teaching environment
Lots to see and  learn - huge learning curve
great experience on the resume as a trauma centre
Camaraderie is high, when things get tuff/complicated -  staff come together to get it done
Finally more male nurses to balance it out
Diverse culture 
Education opportunities (i.e.. monitor training to triage nursing)
cons:
Long 12 hour shifts
staff shortage
hard to get shift changes
if you are low on the seniority pole - good luck getting vacation in the summer
high turnover in staff and some senior staff who should retire due to their burnout bad attitude
MNU - Weak union!

review_title: One of the best jobs I have ever had!
pros:
Regular working hours, Mon- Fri. 
Excellent pay and benefits
Meeting a variety of people
Working with great people
Excellent experience and growth
cons:
Sometimes everyday feels like groundhog day. 
You lose your mental health eventually
Work overload
Working with females only can be somewhat of a challenge, they seem to love drama and backstabbing. Unfortunate.

review_title: Excellent place to work ... but comes with the big government challenges you expect
pros: Huge variety of work. Lots of opportunity to be involved with things that will make a difference to your community. Full defined benefit pension!
cons: Unless you have a medical degree your advancement is severely limited. Due to government cost containment measures salary levels are beginning to lag private sector roles. A lot of burocracy.

pros: Hourly wage is higher than private sector, paid sick leave, vacation and benefits are great.
cons: Program staff treat administrative staff as though we are incompetent.  Bullying is common.  Unfortunately exclusion and racism rampant.  HR is useless.

pros: The WRHA has a great internship program. I learnt a lot and had many opportunities to gain experience in a vast array of health care settings.
cons: With the new provincial government, WRHA has began the process of reviewing the budget. Which has lead to a significant amount of cuts. This is concerning for new up and coming health care professionals.

review_title: Good place to work, opportunities to advance sometimes limited
job_title: Shared Care Mental Health Counsellor in Winnipeg, MB
pros: Good pay, great employees, employees quite passionate about their work, hours of work are flexible, great benefits, professional development is encouraged and funded partially
cons: difficult to advance, directives from senior management not always in line with best practices, nepotism can be evident in some departments, work in silos, although some advancement in information technology still a ways to go

pros: Rate of pay is comparable, if you have an FTE, you get paid guaranteed biweekly hours if you meet all the requirements.
cons: To get paid your guaranteed hours you have to give more hours of availability than you get paid. Office staff will schedule your work from start to finish of your availability, leaving you with gaps of unpaid time and nothing to do but sit in your car. Office staff do not offer respect for your time off, they will call you on your days off, before or after your work day starts and when you are on vacation etc., and for reasons that could wait till you are at work. No real sick days, after probation , to get 1 sick day in your bank, you have to work 520 hours and that sick day is only paid out at 662/3 rate of your pay. Highly stressful but the stress comes from dealing with the admin staff. Clients are great, you get the occasional difficult one but nothing unbearable. Some Supervisors can be helpful but mostly they seek to find what you are doing wrong and if things go wrong, the common way the admin staff deal with it is to pass the buck till it lands at the feed of the Direct Service Staff. You never get willing help from the admin staff. You have to push, push, push. I have worked at this job for over 20 years and it used to be good. Turned crap about 10 years ago.

pros: Winnipeg Regional Health Authority is very accepting of my schedule and I love the benefits that come with it. The work is very rewarding!
cons: Due to the position I am in and where I work, there is not much room to meet others, but I don't think that is the same for everyone.

pros: Unionized so the pay is reasonable.
cons: Fire people while on medical leaves of absences.   Toxic work environments that are not employee friendly.  Assign unreasonable work assignments at the cost of the health of its workers and sometimes the patients.  Take forever to settle union contracts and settling grievances.

pros: Flexible working hours, you will always be busy and have work.
cons: Home health care workers haven't gotten a pay raise in more than 5 years. There is no opportunity for benefits, career advancement, ongoing training.
